awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF:  Collaborative Research:  Augmenting and Advancing Cognitive Performance of Control Room Operators for Power Grid Resiliency
awd_abstract_narration:
The Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier (FW-HTF) is one of 10 new Big Ideas for Future Investment announced by the National Science Foundation. The FW-HTF cross-directorate program aims to respond to the challenges and opportunities of the changing landscape of jobs and work by supporting convergent research. This award fulfills part of that aim. Effective decision making by power grid operators in extreme events (e.g., Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico, the Ukraine cyber attack) depends on two factors: operator knowledge acquired through training and experience, and appropriate decision support tools. Decision making in electric grid operation during extreme adverse events directly impacts the life of citizens. This project will augment the cognitive performance of human operators with new, human-focused decision support tools and better, data-driven training for managing the grid especially under highly disruptive conditions. The development of new generation of tools for online knowledge fusion, event detection, cyber-physical-human analysis in operational environment can be applied during extreme events and provide energy to critical facilities like hospitals, city halls and essential infrastructure to keep citizens safe and avoid economic loss for the Nation. Higher performance of operators will improve worker quality of life and will enhance the economic and social well-being of the country. The project's training objectives will leverage existing educational efforts and outreach activities and we will publicize the multidisciplinary outcomes through multiple venues.


The proposed project will integrate principles from cognitive neuroscience, artificial intelligence, machine learning, data science, cybersecurity, and power engineering to augment power grid operators for better performance. Two key parameters influencing human performance from the dynamic attentional control (DAC) framework are working memory (WM) capacity, the ability to maintain information in the focus of attention, and cognitive flexibility (CF), the ability to use feedback to redirect decision making given fast changing system scenarios. The project will achieve its goals through analyzing WM and CF and performance of power grid operators during extreme events; augmenting cognitive performance through advanced machine learning based decision support tools and adaptive human-machine system; and developing theory-driven training simulators for advancing cognitive performance of human operators for enhanced grid resilience. A new set of algorithms have been proposed for data-driven event detection, anomaly flag processing, root cause analysis and decision support using Tree Augmented naive Bayesian Net (TAN) structure, Minimum Weighted Spanning Tree (MWST) using the Mutual Information (MI) metric, and unsupervised learning improved for online learning and decision making. Additionally, visualization tools have been proposed using cognitive factor analysis and human error analysis. We propose a training process driven by cognitive and physiometric analysis and inspired by our experience in operators training in multiple domain: the power grid, aircraft and spacecraft flight simulators. A systematic approach for human operator decision making is proposed using quantifiable human and engineering analysis indices for power grid resiliency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to develop advanced decision support tools for power grid operators, allowing them to make quicker and more accurate decisions. These tools are developed utilizing knowledge from a wide range of fields, including cognitive neuroscience, artificial intelligence, machine learning, data science, cybersecurity, and power engineering. The power grid is evolving, and without effective tools to process and display this information, operators might struggle to make timely decisions, especially during emergencies. Using our tools, operators can respond to potential problems quickly and effectively, minimizing disruptions and maintaining grid reliability and resiliency.

To test these tools, we built a specialized control room like environment. This setup utilizes data from power grid using electromagnetic realistic simulation, and with simulated cyber-attacks. Power grid control room environment with Human-in-the-Loop (HIL), allows us to observe how real human operators interact with the system during both normal and emergency scenarios. The developed environment integrates an industry-scale Energy Management System (EMS) and in-house developed tools: CP-TRAM for cyber resilience, Cyber-Power Tool for alarm generation, and SyncAEDC for detecting events based on Phasor Measurement Unit (PMU) data. Out tool utilizes statistical data analytics, advanced machine learning, and physics-driven power system information.

In this developed environment, operators use several visualization screens: a Power Simulator, a Cyber-Power Tool that shows alarms for cyber and physical events, and an Operator Manual for guidelines. Eye-tracking glasses monitor where the operators are looking, while sensors capture their physiological responses. This allows us to evaluate their cognitive flexibility — their ability to adapt and make quick decisions as the situation changes.

One key finding was that operators who used our Cyber-Power Tool performed significantly better in complex scenarios. This tool consolidates data into a user-friendly interface that clearly displays both cyber and physical event alarms. It allows operators to immediately see which events are most critical, enabling quicker and more informed decision-making. In scenarios without this tool, operators often missed critical cyber-related information due to the overwhelming amount of data and not being trained to deal with physical anomalies caused by cyber events.

For example, when the Cyber-Power Tool was available, all 18 operators with industry experience in our study accurately detected simulated cyber events and took timely action. Without the tool, only 3 operators were able to identify the cyber threats. Our findings were backed by detailed eye-tracking data, which showed distinct differences in how operators allocated their attention. When using the Cyber-Power Tool, operators' gaze was focused on relevant data, confirming that the tool effectively guided their attention. In contrast, without the tool, operators' eye movements were scattered, indicating that they struggled to pinpoint important information amid the noise.

The research also highlighted the importance of cognitive flexibility in power system operators. In complex and dynamic environments, the ability to shift focus, adapt strategies, and react to unexpected changes is vital. Our tools were also designed to reduce cognitive load. In high-pressure situations, information overload can lead to slower, less accurate decisions. This visual focus was reinforced by eye-tracking heatmaps, which showed that operators spent more time on relevant areas of the screen, indicating a clearer understanding of what information mattered most.

The Cyber-Power Testbed also allowed us to evaluate how well operators adhered to procedural guidelines when responding to different types of events, such as purely physical incidents, isolated cyber events, and complex scenarios where cyber-attacks led to physical consequences. By observing operators’ behavior across these scenarios, we gathered data on how they navigated the system and how their decision-making strategies evolved. These observations were important in fine-tuning our tools and identifying areas for improvement.

Another notable aspect of the study was the use of eye-tracking technology to calculate a "cognitive flexibility score" for each operator. This score was derived from metrics like gaze duration, fixation points, and the fluidity of transitions between different areas of interest. These metrics helped us assess how well operators adapted to changing conditions and how effectively they utilized the available tools. Operators who scored high in cognitive flexibility tended to perform better, managing complex scenarios with greater accuracy and speed. This suggests that cognitive flexibility is a key skill for power system operators, especially as the grid becomes more interconnected and data-rich. Our work has led to substantial scientific contributions to the field, including two completed theses, a book chapter, 21 journal articles, 17 conference articles, and numerous presentations.

As a result of this research, we have laid a strong foundation for future workforce of power grid operators and training programs that will better prepare operators to respond to physical threats caused by cyber events and extreme weather events.
